Agaricus.description: Common edible genus, including the mushrooms you buy in the store (Agaricus bisporus). Often found in lawns and meadows. Gills start pink and turn dark brown with age.
distinguishing_features: Gills are pink (when young) to dark brown (when mature).
Does NOT have a volva (cup) at the base of the stem.
Spore print is dark brown.
Agaricus.safety_warning: CRITICAL: Must be distinguished from deadly Amanita species (which have white gills, a white spore print, and a volva at the base).

Amanita.description: Genus containing some of the most toxic mushrooms known. Responsible for the majority of fatal mushroom poisonings. Avoid if unsure.
distinguishing_features: Gills are almost always white.
Spore print is white.
Has a 'volva' (a sac-like cup) at the base of the stem (may be underground).
Often has a 'ring' or 'skirt' on the stem.
Amanita.safety_warning: Default assumption for any Amanita is **DEADLY**. Never consume. The 'Destroying Angel' (Amanita bisporigera) looks just like an edible Field Mushroom.

Boletus.description: A group of fleshy, thick-capped mushrooms with pores instead of gills. Many are prized edibles, like the King Bolete (Porcini).
distinguishing_features: Has a spongy layer of PORES underneath the cap instead of gills.
Many species 'bluise' or change color when cut or bruised.
Flesh is thick and solid.
Boletus.safety_warning: While many are prized, some boletes are bitter, poisonous, or cause gastric distress. Avoid any boletes that have red or deep orange pores.

Cortinarius.description: A massive genus of mushrooms. Many are notoriously difficult to identify and some are deadly toxic, attacking the kidneys. Do not eat unless confident.
distinguishing_features: Young specimens have a 'cortina' (a cobweb-like partial veil) covering the gills.
Spore print is rust-brown (this often dusts the stem and cortina).
Cortinarius.safety_warning: Consider all Cortinarius species toxic. Some, like the Deadly Webcap, can cause kidney failure weeks after ingestion. Not a genus for beginners.

Entoloma.description: A large, diverse genus known for its characteristic pink spore print. Many are small, brown, and hard to identify. Identification is critical.
distinguishing_features: Spore print is salmon-pink.
Spores are angular (visible under a microscope).
Gills are typically 'attached' to the stem (not free).
Entoloma.safety_warning: Many species are poisonous, most famously the 'Livid Pinkgill' (Entoloma sinuatum). Can be confused with edible species.

Hygrocybe.description: Known as waxcaps. They are often small, brightly colored (red, orange, yellow), and have a waxy or greasy feel.
distinguishing_features: Cap and gills often feel waxy or moist.
Often brightly colored (red, orange, yellow, green).
Gills are often thick, widely spaced, and attached to the stem.
Hygrocybe.safety_warning: While most are considered edible (or at least not poisonous), their small size makes them less desirable. Primarily indicators of old, unimproved grassland.

Lactarius.description: Known as milkcaps. Their defining feature is that they exude a 'latex' or 'milk' when the gills or flesh are cut. Some are edible.
distinguishing_features: Exudes a milky latex (e.g., white, orange, red) when cut or damaged.
Flesh is brittle and snaps like chalk (similar to Russula).
Lactarius.safety_warning: Edibility depends on the species and the taste/color of the milk. Many with white, acrid (peppery) milk are toxic. Some, like the Saffron Milkcap (orange milk), are edible.

Russula.description: Known as brittlegills. A very large genus with hundreds of species, often with brightly colored caps (red, green, purple). Handle with care.
distinguishing_features: The stem snaps cleanly in two, like a piece of chalk (brittle flesh).
Gills are often white to cream and brittle.
Often have very colorful caps.
Russula.safety_warning: Many species are acrid (peppery) and will cause gastric upset. A common (but not 100% reliable) rule for experts is that mild-tasting species are edible, and acrid ones are not.

Suillus.description: A genus of boletes (pore-surface, not gills) that are almost exclusively found growing with conifer trees like pines and firs. Mostly edible.
distinguishing_features: Has pores, not gills.
Cap is often slimy, sticky, or 'slippery' (especially when wet).
Found under conifer trees.
Often has a ring on the stem.
Suillus.safety_warning: Most are edible, but many people remove the slimy cap cuticle before cooking as it can have a laxative effect or cause stomach upset.
